propertyDescriptions.Dataset: Use this section to capture domain-specific information about the dataset, including data modality, acquisition technique, processing stage, domain standards used to arrange and annotate the data, and access information about source data, if available.

title: Human cognitive neuroscience data (v1) template schema

_ui._content:
About the metadata template

Are you afraid nobody can find your opened dataset in cognitive neuroscience?

The template aims to generate and share standardized metadata of cognitive neuroscience research projects with human subjects, to enrich publicly accessible domain-specific metadata, and subsequently enhance the discoverability/searchability and reusability of the shared resource. 

This metadata template was developed by the research team at the Max Planck Institute of Empirical Aesthetics in collaboration with DataCite. The template was built as part of the Implementing FAIR Workflows Project (TWCF0568), funded by the Templeton World Charity Foundation.

The template was built with the Center for Expanded Data Annotation and Retrieval (CEDAR) Workbench. Learn more about CEDAR metadata templates here.

Feel free to contact Zefan Zheng per email if you have any questions about the metadata template.

Tips for completing this form

1. Hover the cursor on to show the field description, and onto show the ontological scope assigned to the field.

2. For fields assigned with ontological support, the drop-down menu may contain too many items making it hard to navigate. To ease navigation, enter the first letters of your desired value, the form will attempt to autocomplete your entry with standardized vocabulary. 

3. Some concepts have different expressions, enter several of them if the field does not respond with the correct terminology, i.e. try "functional magnetic resonance imaging" instead of "fMRI".

4. Fields or elements (multiple fields under one heading) that are repeatable are indicated by at the top right corner, use the "Copy" button to duplicate the field or element, or use the "Toggle View" button to call a table view for metadata entry.

5. Leave the field blank if the information is unavailable or not applicable.

propertyDescriptions.Data Standard: Community data standard according to which the dataset is organized. i.e. the standardized structure of data formatting and storing. Select all that's applicable, If choose "Other", provide link to standard specification in the following field.
propertyDescriptions.Reference to Data Standard: Provide link to authoritative documentation on the data standard used for the dataset. Use a persistent identifier (i.e. DOI) when possible.

propertyDescriptions.Analysis Pipeline: Information about the preprocess used to produce the dataset. Please provide the link to the documentation or publication describing the analysis process, using DOI when possible. (e.g. Brainlife workflow publication).   Leave the field blank if not applicable.
propertyDescriptions.Preprocessing Script: Provide a link to the location where the preprocessing code is hosted, i.e. GitHub repository.   To ensure the accessibility and compatibility of the code, consider depositing a copy of the code together with the dataset following the Dryad submission process.  Leave the field blank if not applicable.

propertyDescriptions.Statistic Model: Statistic tests used in the analysis scripts.  This entry is supported by an auto-fill function. It is recommended to type in the most relevant word and wait for matching ontologies to show up below, among which you choose the most relevant ones. If no direct matching, try other keywords and pick one that is closest to your answer. If no matching at all, please leave this field blank.
propertyDescriptions.Analysis Pipeline: If the given analysis scripts have employed existing standardised analysis pipeline, please provide the link to the documentation describing the analysis pipeline, using a DOI when possible. (e.g. Brainlife workflow publication)
propertyDescriptions.Programming Language: The language in which analysis code is written, intended to be executed/ran by a software interpreter. Please enter the language of the code that is uploaded along with the dataset.  The field is supported by the Software Ontology, If the language you used is not listed, please leave this field blank and use the following field (Programming Language (Other)) to indicate the name of the language.

Analysis.schema:name: Analysis

propertyDescriptions.Protocol: An experimental protocol is a description of procedure or list of procedures performed (see protocol.io as reference). Provide a link to the publicly accessible record of the protocol. Use a persistent identifier i.e. DOI if possible. Leave blank if does not apply.
propertyDescriptions.Clinical Trial: A clinical trial is a research study that prospectively assigns human participants or groups of humans to one or more health-related interventions to evaluate the effects on health outcomes. If the dataset is produced during a clinical trial experiment, please provide the link to the trial registration. (Use persistent identifier i.e. DOI when possible.) Leave blank if does not apply.
propertyDescriptions.Preregistration: Preregistration is a practice of documenting your research plan at the beginning of your study and storing that plan in a read-only public repository such as OSF Registries or the National Library of Medicine's Clinical Trials Registry. Provide a link to the publicly accessible record of the preregistration. Use a persistent identifier i.e. DOI if possible. Leave blank if does not apply.
propertyDescriptions.Area of Research: The field of research that is intended for study, based on this collected dataset (e.g. memory, decision-making, consciousness, etc). The field is supported by ontological terms in the Concept category of Cognitive Atlas Ontology.   This entry is supported by an auto-fill function. It is recommended to type in the most relevant word and wait for matching ontologies to show up below, among which you choose the most relevant ones. If no direct matching, try other keywords and pick one that is closest to your field.  If no relevant matching at all, you can either forward to Cognitive Atlas to add your area of research to the Concept category or leave this field blank. But contribution to experimental ontology building will make your research significantly more discoverable.

Subject.schema:name: Subject

propertyDescriptions.Response: The primary response types participants have made to create the dataset.   Options include: blink, breath-hold, button press, draw, drink, extension, finger tapping, grasp, manipulate, micturate, point, saccades, smile response, speech, swallow, whistle, write, and implicit response.  This entry is supported by a multiple-choice auto-fill function. Please type in the most relevant option mentioned above and wait for the matching ontology to show up below.   If no relevant matching at all, please leave this field blank.
propertyDescriptions.Stimulus: The generic stimulus type presented to participants to collect the dataset (e.g., words, faces, breathable gas).   This entry is supported by an auto-fill function. Please type in the most relevant option mentioned above and wait for the matching ontology to show up below.   If no relevant matching at all, please leave this field blank.
propertyDescriptions.Publication: If a scientific article has been published using the current dataset, please provide the DOI of the pre-print or the article in peer-reviewed journals.
propertyDescriptions.Sensory Type: If external sensory stimuli are presented during the experiment, please specify the sensory modality of the stimuli.
propertyDescriptions.Area of Interest: Indicate which anatomical area is of interests in this study if neural data is recorded.   This entry is supported by an auto-fill function. It is recommended to type in the most relevant word and wait for matching ontologies to show up below, among which you choose the most relevant ones. If no direct matching, try other keywords and pick one that is closest to your answer. If no relevant matching at all, please leave this field blank.
propertyDescriptions.Experimental Paradigm: The experimental paradigms employed in the experiment to collect the dataset (e.g., n-back task, attentional blink).  This entry is supported by an auto-fill function. It is recommended to type in the most relevant word and wait for matching ontologies to show up below, among which you choose the most relevant ones. If no direct matching, try other keywords and pick one that is closest to your field.  If no relevant matching at all, you can either forward to Cognitive Atlas to add your area of research to the  Task category or leave this field blank. But contribution to experimental ontology building will make your research significantly more discoverable.
propertyDescriptions.Experimental Instruction: The primary experimental instructions given to participants to collect the dataset.   Options include: attend, count, detect, discriminate, encode, fixate, generate, imagine, move, name, read, recall, repeat, rest, sing, smile instructions, track.  This entry is supported by an auto-fill function. Please type in the most relevant option mentioned above and wait for the matching ontology to show up below.   If no relevant matching at all, please leave this field blank.

If the dataset is produced during a clinical trial experiment, please provide the link to the trial registration. (Use persistent identifier i.e. DOI when possible.) Leave blank if does not apply.

If no relevant matching at all, you can either forward to Cognitive Atlas to add your area of research to the Concept category or leave this field blank. But contribution to experimental ontology building will make your research significantly more discoverable.
